animalOfTheDay.name: worm
facts: Earthworms have five hearts and breathe through skin.
They improve soil aeration – moving 20 tons of earth per acre annually.
Worms regenerate segments; some species regrow heads.
Charles Darwin studied earthworms for 40 years, calling them 'nature's ploughs'.

calendar.name: water buffalo
facts: Wild water buffaloes are endangered; only 3,400 remain in fragmented habitats.
Domesticated for 5,000 years, they provide more milk than dairy cows in some regions.
They wallow in water to cool down and deter biting insects.
Water buffaloes have wide-splayed hooves preventing sinking in mud.

calendar.name: wild boar
facts: Sows build 'farrowing nests' of woven grass before giving birth.
Wild boars have razor-sharp tusks that regrow continuously.
Boars run 30 mph and jump 5-ft fences.
They create 'boar baths' – mud wallows that cool and remove parasites.

calendar.name: wild dog
facts: They regurgitate food for pups, elders, and injured pack members.
Packs hold territories up to 900 square miles.
African wild dogs vote to hunt via sneezing – more sneezes trigger departures.
Wild dogs have mottled coats unique to each individual.

calendar.name: wombat
facts: Wombats produce cube-shaped feces – unique among animals – to prevent rolling.
They dig complex burrows with multiple entrances and sleeping chambers.
They can run 25 mph despite stubby legs.
Wombat rear hides have cartilage plates – blocking dingo bites when fleeing to tunnels.

calendar.name: woodpecker
facts: Acorn woodpeckers drill thousands of holes to store acorns – 'granary trees'.
Their tongues wrap around skulls to cushion brains during pecking.
Woodpeckers have shock-absorbing skulls and compressible brain cases.
Pileated woodpeckers create rectangular holes in trees searching for ants.

calendar.name: woolly mammoth
facts: Permafrost-preserved mammoths provide DNA for de-extinction projects.
Their curved tusks measured 16 ft – used for clearing snow to reach grass.
Woolly mammoths had fur up to 3 ft long and 4-inch fat layers for insulation.
Mammoths survived on Wrangel Island until 1650 BCE – contemporary with Egyptian pyramids.

Worms regenerate segments; some species regrow heads.
Earthworms have five hearts and breathe through skin.
Charles Darwin studied earthworms for 40 years, calling them 'nature's ploughs'.

randomAnimals.name: squid
facts: Squid have three hearts: two pump blood to the gills, and one pumps it to the rest of the body.
They can change color rapidly to communicate or camouflage, using specialized cells called chromatophores.
The giant squid is the largest invertebrate, with eyes the size of dinner plates.
Some squid species can 'fly' by propelling themselves out of the water and gliding for short distances.

Boars run 30 mph and jump 5-ft fences.
They create 'boar baths' – mud wallows that cool and remove parasites.
Wild boars have razor-sharp tusks that regrow continuously.

randomAnimals.name: parakeet
facts: Parakeets are small, long-tailed parrots that are highly social and intelligent.
They can learn to mimic human speech and sounds with training.
In the wild, they live in large flocks that can number in the thousands.
Parakeets form strong pair bonds and often preen each other's feathers.
